results.title: Men like me
results.creator_credit: Sylvie Shaw, Wild Cat Productions, Film Victoria and Susan Long
results.brief_description: ‘Men Like Me’ is the story of Dale Michaels, who changed his sexual identity from female to male. It is also an account of the filmmaker’s response to a friend’s need to change their identity and what that entailed. The film is a collaboration between the filmmaker and Dale Michaels and was made in 1994 when female to male transgender was relatively unfamiliar to the broader community and rarely discussed. Informative and sensitively presented using interviews, vox pops, archival footage and stills, combined with computer animated images and narration by Susan Long and Dale Michaels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sylvie Shaw, Wild Cat Productions, Film Victoria and Susan Long

results.title: Men in wool
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Designed to show the importance of wool in the manufacture of men’s clothing, tracking the cycle from the shearing shed to the tailored suit. Illustrates the process of shearing, grading, scouring and carding and explains the range of tests for strength, elasticity and possible imperfections. Finally shows the manufacture of a suit using mass productions and hand tailoring techniques. Photographed by George Heath; narrated by Michael Charlton; edited by Les Wasley; script by John Moyes Junior; sound by Allyn Barnes.

results.title: Men in white
results.brief_description:
What motivates someone to become an umpire? Clinton Markwell and Lockie Eccles at Warrnambool provide some answers.

Thank you to Clinton Markwell, Robert Eccles, Tom Greenaway, and the Warrnambool and District Football Umpires Association. Archival film reproduced courtesy of Hampden FNL.

TRANSCRIPT

[WHISTLE]

-The idea of having a green shirt is to signify that we’re a learner umpire and just to give us a fair go, I guess. And just like if you’re in a car, you see a learner driver, you know to just be patient with them. And just to understand that they are still learning and that it’s an important part of their career.

[WHISTLE]

I played one season of, like, under-twelves football. And I’m a bit of a wimp, so I don’t, just not cut out for football, so I’ve decided to come up and umpire. Over four years that I’ve been here, I’ve just decided that I love it, and I love football, and that’s why I stayed.

-When I first walked into the umpire fraternity, the track supervisor at the stage, he firstly said, come on, young fellow, here’s the ball. Took me over to the point pace, and he said, showed me the basics of hanging on and holding the ball. And he said, now, I want you to bounce this ball up and down at this point pace. It’s gotta be straight up and down it, and it’s also got to reach the top of it.

So for two weeks or so I practiced and I practiced. After a couple of weeks, I, yeah, I mastered it. And so I went over to the track supervisor Roy. And I said, Roy, I’ve done it, where do I go next?

He says, no son, come here. We’ve moved to the goal post now. And I said, what? And he said, now I want you to do it up and down the goal post and to the height of the goal post.

It’s a skill, and we’ve lost it in the country because we throw the ball up. But for the young fellas, my mentees, it’s a case that will be taught, and I hope to pass that skill onto them.

-Well, I’ll have to learn how to bounce it one day for I want to go to the AFL, which I do. It’d be a dream one day walking around the MCG with all the 100,000 people roaring. But yeah, I’ll just let it take me and enjoy the ride, I reckon.

-It’s put another spring in my step doing this mentoring program, because these young fellas, I can see that possibility that I’d hope one will make it to AFL.

[WHISTLE]

-Basically, he works with me and pass on his knowledge of how to umpire and how to treat players, which is a fundamental aspect of being an umpire. I’m nervous every single game just because the fellas there, they’re another foot taller than me and just, I don’t know, there’s a lot of expectations of me to perform.

[WHISTLE]

I just do it because I love it, and it’s a great game.

results.title: Men in crisis
results.brief_description: Discusses how after a decade of Russian domination, the people of Hungary launch a desperate battle from freedom in 1956, how their appeal to the free world is rejected and their Prime Minster Nagy is imprisoned.
results.description: Discusses how after a decade of Russian domination, the people of Hungary launch a desperate battle from freedom in 1956, how their appeal to the free world is rejected and their Prime Minster Nagy is imprisoned.

results.title: Men in black (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Amblin Entertainment, MacDonald Parkes Productions, Walter Parkes, Laurie MacDonald and Barry Sonenfield
results.brief_description: The talents behind this special effects bonanza are onto something special - lovely laser-keen wit that comes at warp speed, with modesty and effortless cool. With a new alien critter roughly every 10 minutes - only the sheer presence of the main actors Tommy Lee Jones and Wil Smith keeps them from being upstaged. They are the best kept secret in the universe, their mission is to monitor extra-terrestrial activity on earth. They are our best, last and only line of defence. They work in secret, they exist in shadow - they are the Men in Black! Based on the comic by Lowell Cunningham.

results.title: Men for others
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Vincent Tovell
results.brief_description: Discusses the tole of the church in our modern society, and its attempts to find a new way in a secular world. The letters of Nazi martyr, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, form a basis for a new look church. Scientific development, increasing man’s power of construction and destruction has also increased his moral responsibility. Social injustices suffered by the coloured races are presented as the greatest challenge to the church and man today.

results.title: Men at work
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, ONF | NFB and Donald Peters
results.brief_description: A story of men and machines, of the difficulty of adjusting everyone to the standardized needs of modern industry. Photographed in a washing machine factory, the film shows what happens from the humans relations point of view when a speeded-up conveyor system and a clash of temperaments disrupt the harmonious work of a group of men on an assembly line.

results.title: Men at work
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of introducing Work Study into industry. In one of the departments of a factory there is a bottleneck in production. It is decided to bring in a Work Study expert to see if the job can be streamlined. The worker mainly affected, remembering the hard times of the ‘thirties, convinces his workmates that although he is the only one threatened, it might be their turn next. They are behind him and there is not only trouble for the firm but also the unions whose agreement with the firm sanctions the introduction of Work Study. Rumours of impending sackings spread, tempters get short, but the shop steward reassures the men that they will not lose. The situation is resolved. One man is transferred to a job in another department and when he is being re-trained for it, his pay is being made up. The bottleneck which started the trouble is eliminated and the central character - the worker who feared the sack if the if the Work Study reorganisation took place, now finds himself actually earning more, even though, as a result of the re-arrangement, he is doing the job single-handed.
